paragraph.docTitle:
Cloning and functional characterization of a TMC-like channel gene and protein in the crayfish
Astacus leptodactylus ( Eschscholtz, 1823 )
( Decapoda : Astacidea: Astacidae )

subSection.paragraph:
Kaan Arslan 1, , Berk Saglam 1, , Nazli Coskun Beyatli 1 , Ekim Z. Taskiran
2
, Turgut Bastug 1 and Nuhan Purali 1,

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Biophysics, Faculty of Medicine, Hacettepe University, 06100 Ankara , Turkey
Department of Medical Genetics, Faculty of Medicine, Hacettepe University, 06100 Ankara , Turkey

subSection.paragraph: Correspondance: N. Purali:e-mail:npurali@hacettepe.edu.tr

heading.emphasis: A B ST R A CT

subSection.paragraph:
Ion channels gated selectively by mechanical stimulus are the key elements of mechanosensation. Several genes have been associated with putative mechanosensitive ion channels or mechanosensitive channel complexes. Transmembrane channel (TMC)-like protein is one of those candidate proteins that have been explored in mammals and several invertebrates. The presence and possible function of TMC related genes has not been investigated yet in crustaceans. In the present work an mRNA coding TMC-like protein was firstly cloned in
Astacus leptodactylus ( Eschscholtz, 1823 )
( Decapoda : Astacidea: Astacidae ) and expressed in HEK293T cells. Three-dimensional structural calculations of the protein predicted a channel. Functional studies, however, indicated that the mechanosensitivity of the transfected HEK293T cells is similar to that in the control cells. It was concluded that a TMC-like protein is present in the crayfish but future studies are necessary to define its function.

paragraph.heading: KEY WORDS: cloning , Crustacea , mechanosensation , transmembrane channel

subSection.paragraph: Cells are susceptible to many different kinds of stimuli, one of which is mechanical force. Some cells have evolved to sense mechanical force specifically, and it has been shown that the mechanical stimulus evokes ionic currents in some cells due to an increase in the membrane conductance. The change in the conductance is generated by a unique type of ion channel, gated preferably by the mechanical force only, classified as mechanically activated or mechanosensitive ion channels.

The RACE-PCR experiments resulted in ~700 and ~1,500 base pairs of fragments in size for the 5 ʹ and 3 ʹ ends, respectively. Sequencing of these fragments revealed the complete TMC mRNA including the open reading frame (ORF) and the untranslated regions in both ends (GenBank accession number: ON604003) ( Fig. 1B ).

In order to compare the expression level of ganglia and muscle tissues we used available hundreds of millions of short reads of cDNA libraries. Equalized number of short reads were Bowtie mapped to TMC mRNA sequence in DNASTAR platform. Short read hits were compered. Calculations indicated a fourfold larger mRNA expression in the ganglia tissues.

The three-dimensional structure of the cloned channel protein was calculated by using various open access web based facilities. Results obtained in I-TASSER and AlphaFold were rather limited due to the size restrictions of the platforms, but we obtained a successful calculation of the complete structure in the SWISS-MODEL platform. The quaternary structure quality estimation (QSQE), sequence similarity, and coverage scores of the calculation were 0.33, 0.33, and 0.73, respectively ( Fig. 3 ). The calculated three dimensional structure of the cloned protein is very similar to that of
Caenorhabditis elegans
tmc-1 protein NP_508221.3), but the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein is much larger in size compared to the other TMC sequences including the cloned protein in
Astacus leptodactylus
. As shown in Fig. 3D , the calculated structure of the cloned sequence aligned well to the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein structure. The SWISS-Model homology calculation had ten transmembrane domains as in the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein. The calculated pore forming transmembrane segments of the
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein, TM4, and TM8, aligned to the segments between 220–247 and 648–670 residues of the cloned protein, respectively.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 1. Gel photograph of the gene fragment amplified in a PCR by using F1_tmc1 and R1_tmc1 primers in ganglia cDNA template of
Astacus leptodactylus
( A ). Gel photograph of the ORF of the cloned mRNA amplified in a PCR by using F1_tmc_mScarlet, R1_tmc_mScarlet primers in ganglia cDNA template ( B ). Ladders are 100 bp (A) and 1 kbp (B).

subSection.paragraph: Cultured HEK293T cells were transfected with ‘tmc_mScarlet’ plasmid using Lipofectamine 3000 Transfection Reagent (Thermo-Fisher Scientific) and observed under a confocal microscope after 48 h. The transfected cells emitted a red

caption.paragraph: Table 1. Primer sequences (5 ʹ –3 ʹ ) used for PCR, RACE-PCR and In-Fusion assembly reactions

subSection.paragraph: F1_tmc1 GTCGTCCTCCTCTTCTCCATCTATC
F2_tmc1 TCCAAGACATACACTTACCCTGGTTC
R1_tmc1 AGTCACTGCTGGAAGTATTGGAGAG
F3_tmc1 CAGCAGAAGAGGGTCAGACACATAC
tmc_3F ATCAGCCAGTGTTCACCTCCAGAGCCTG
tmc_5R TTGACAACTTGAAGGCTGCCAGACCACG
F1_tmc_mScarlet ACCGCGGTGGCGGCCAAGACGAGAGGAAGGAAATGG
R1_tmc_mScarlet TGACTCCTGCAGGCGAAGTAGAAACAGCATTCACGTCTG

The Fluo-4 AM-loaded HEK293T cells were poked with a blunt microelectrode to test if the cloned channel is sensitive to mechanical stimulus. A rise in calcium-specific emission signal in response to mechanical stimulation was considered as an indicator of a calcium influx through the mechanosensitive channels. The experiments were conducted on both transfected and control cells and results were compared. As shown in Figure 5A , the results were inconclusive as they failed to show any statistically significant difference between the transfected and control cells in these sample sizes. Peak amplitudes of the recorded calcium signals were statistically similar in both groups (control group 31.81 ± 12.86, mean ± SD, N = 5, transfected cells 21.36 ± 16.59, mean ± SD, N = 5, P = 0.29). Transfected cells were mechanically stimulated by application of fluid jets from a micro-pipette that were produced by using a pneumatic injector. The maximum amplitudes of the evoked calcium response to fluid jets were similar when the results from test and control cells were compared (control group 6.57 ± 4.10, mean ± SD, N = 6, transfected cells 11.99 ± 12.08, mean ± SD, N = 6, P = 0.32) ( Fig. 5B ). The possible effects of extracellular sodium concentration were investigated in another experimental group. The bath solution was substituted with a solution containing 167 mM sodium while the calcium sensitive emission was acquired continuously. The amplitudes of the change in the signal were similar in both groups (control group 1.07 ± 1.07, mean ± SD, N = 4, transfected cells 3.76 ± 2.85, mean ± SD, N = 4, P = 0.12) ( Fig. 5C ).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 3. Calculated three-dimensional structure of the cloned TMC protein of
Astacus leptodactylus
. Side ( A ), top ( B ),and bottom ( C ) views. Images of the monomer are in ‘ResID’ mode. Dimerised
C. elegans
tmc-1 protein (in ‘Cartoon/Chain’ mode) as cloned protein superimposed onto one of its monomers in ‘NewRibbons’ mode (green) ( D ).

subSection.paragraph:
The TMC protein is present in many phyla, including some invertebrates ( Fig. 2A ). There are a few putative TMC sequences included in shotgun transcriptome assemblies and genome drafts (
Xu et al ., 2021
).
Astacus leptodactylus
mRNA is the first crustacean species to be cloned.

Considering the strong similarity in sequence and structure, it is conceivable to propose that the cloned mRNA may code a TMC-like channel protein in the crayfish. It has been reported that TMC functions as a part of a mechanosensitive channel complex in the hair cells. The lack of any transcript, orthologues to TMIE and protocadherin, in the transcriptome draft raises the question that if the cloned channel protein may independently be mechanosensitive. Plasmid transfection and subsequent functional studies did not enable a significant mechanosensitive activity in HEK293T cells. This might be the result of unsuccessful expression of the cloned protein as a functional channel in the surface membrane. It may be interpreted, however, that mScarlet expression indicates only the successful function of the plasmid. A channel complex might be mandatory as it is in the inner ear for a mechanosensitive channel to activate. Further, functional studies indicate that the cloned protein may not possess sodium sensitivity as reported in
C. elegans
tmc-1 channel. Cell shrinkage by osmotic changes due to increase in the sodium ion concentration might be the cause of the observed rise in the emission ( Fig. 5C ) (see
Chatzigeorgiou et al ., 2013
). The large variance observed in the recorded emission signals may have limited the discriminative power of the statistical evaluation. The variance might stem from the limited precision of the mechanical stimulation at a single-cell level.

Although an mRNA was cloned, coding a protein similar in sequence and structure to those of the mechanosensitive TMC family proteins, functional studies nevertheless do not indicate that the transfected HEK293T cells gained any additional statistically significant mechanosensitive component as compared to the control cells. The sample sizes, particularly for fluid jet and osmotic shock applications, might not have been enough for a statistically significant result. Additional research is needed to define the function of the cloned crayfish TMC-like protein.

paragraph.heading: ACK N O W LE D G E M E N TS

subSection.paragraph: The research was supported by grants from Hacettepe University Research Foundation (HU project 19942, 19692), The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TUBITAK project 218S553). KA received a stipend from the Higher Education Council of Turkey and The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (YOK 100/2000, TUBITAK BIDEB 2211). The authors declare no conflict of interest and would like to thank the Associate Editor, Editor-in- Chief, and the anonymous reviewers.
